title: mind the gap: how to represent partial data
author: Amy Esselman
description:
When sharing data for an incomplete reporting period, being deliberate 
about context will avoid confusion. Read how to take care to differentiate 
between complete and incomplete information with thoughtful design changes.

title: celebrating a decade of storytelling with data
author: Cole Nussbaumer Knaflic
description:
The 10th anniversary edition of storytelling with data is here—with 
refreshed examples, new insights, and a live celebration event you won’t 
want to miss!

title: when bars win—and when lines do
author: Cole Nussbaumer Knaflic
description:
Bars and lines may seem simple—but knowing when to use which is where the 
magic happens. See two makeovers from our new book that reveal how design 
choices can sharpen your message.

title: when decluttering isn’t enough
author: Simon Rowe
description:
Decluttering a visual is an important first step—but it’s not the last. In 
this post, we explore how refining beyond redundant elements and default 
settings can reveal the real story your data is trying to tell.

title: calling all superfans…
author: Cole Nussbaumer Knaflic
description:
Introducing a special superfan program to help promote the 10th anniversary 
edition of storytelling with data. Join the team and earn exclusive perks.

title: the audience will tell you
author: Alex Velez
description:
When communicating data, your audience decides how to show your data. See 
how this core principle helps Alex design one of the makeovers from 
storytelling with data: before & after.

title: what happened when my dad picked up “before & after”
author: Mike Cisneros
description:
I didn’t expect my dad—who never reads for fun—to tackle even a single 
chapter of our new book. But when he did, what he saw in those graphs and 
in our work surprised us both.

title: limit the minutes and let the slides slide
author: Alex Velez
description:
Fewer slides doesn’t automatically lead to shorter presentations. 
Unfortunately, imposing a slide restriction can actually encourage dense 
and confusing slides. Try to prioritize minutes and not slide count.

title: dashboards that deliver: a special #SWDchallenge
author: Mike Cisneros & Amanda Makulec
description:
Dashboards evolve as user needs change, so revisions happen in the real 
world. This month, the teams behind the upcoming books Dashboards That 
Deliver and storytelling with data: before & after invite you to revisit an 
old dashboard that could use a refresh and refocus.

title: knowing is one thing, doing is another
author: Amy Esselman
description:
Amy modifies a busy slide into a compelling data story, using the process 
taught in our 8-week online course. Read the article for a special discount 
to join our next cohort on September 15, 2025.

title: my favorite makeover (that didn’t make the book)
author: Mike Cisneros
description:
This client case makeover—one of our favorites that almost made it into the 
new book—shows how simplifying a complex forecast can turn confusion into 
clarity and insight.

title: a glimpse inside our latest book
author: Alex Velez
description:
Our upcoming book, storytelling with data: before & after, features 20 
real-world makeovers of graphs, reports, scorecards, executive summaries 
and presentations. Read the article for a free sample.

title: connections, culture, and an unforgettable workshop
author: Simon Rowe
description:
Thoughtful planning, diverse voices, and creative touches turn this 
immersive workshop in Trinidad into a memorable example of what helps 
in-person learning shine.

title: tough crowds: how to build trust (and stay motivated)
author: Mike Cisneros
description:
Practical strategies for building trust, overcoming skepticism, and staying 
motivated when sharing data feels like an uphill battle.

title: trust the process
author: Cole Nussbaumer Knaflic
description:
See Cole transform a table into an informative visual, as she shares a 
sneak peek at one of the examples she’ll revisit in the upcoming free 
virtual live event on June 26th.

title: thoughtful transitions for smoother delivery
author: Amy Esselman
description:
Strategic shifts in tone, language, and visuals can quietly shape how your 
message lands and how smoothly your story flows.

title: from conference rooms to cookouts: how to practice public speaking
author: Mike Cisneros
description:
Everyday moments outside the spotlight can help you build the skills and 
comfort to speak with confidence when it counts.

title: you don’t always need a graph!
author: Alex Velez
description:
A heartfelt data journey reveals how sometimes, the most powerful story 
comes not from charts—but from choosing a simpler, more human way to show 
progress.

title: the pain—and power—of editing
author: Cole Nussbaumer Knaflic
description:
Behind every polished story is a messy, meticulous process that turns rough 
drafts into something remarkable—one small fix at a time.

title: your QBR KPIs need an FAQ
author: Mike Cisneros
description:
When every slide is packed with shorthand, the real message can get 
lost—clear language isn’t just polite, it’s powerful.

title: are you sitting comfortably? 3 tips for a stellar presentation
author: Simon Rowe
description:
A shift in setup sparked fresh insight into how voice, visuals, and 
flexibility can carry the moment—even when you’re not on your feet.

title: data detectives: a new way to inspire young learners
author: Cole Nussbaumer Knaflic
description:
A playful new program sparks curiosity and confidence in kids by showing 
them how data can help solve real-world mysteries—and you can be a part of 
it!
